question: which of the following is the correct statement regarding Huntington's chorea?
options:
a)It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder
b)There is loss of function type of mutation
c)There are abnormal repeats of CUG
d)Abnormality is seen due to mutation in chromosome 6
solution:
Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder.
It is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder. It is caused by CAG
trinucleotide repeats (>4o). It occurs due to a gain-of-function (expansion) mutation in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4p.
The disease shows genetic anticipation and has an early-onset (2-3 decades) if inherited from the father.
Cognitive impairment is an early feature. pathologically, atrophy of caudate and putamen with ex vacuo ventriculomegaly is seen. Decreased acetylcholine leads to dementia and decreased GABA   and increased dopamine lead to chorea.
Treatment consists of haloperidol and tetrabenazine.
Trinucleotide repeat disorders:

Disease	Repe ats	Clinical features
Fragile X- syndrome	CGG	Mental retardation, large ear s, and jaws, macroorchidism in males
Myotonic Dystrophy(chromo some 19)	CTG	Muscle loss, cardiac arrhyth   mia,cataracts, frontal balding
Huntington’s disease	CAG	Affective disorder
spinocerebellar ataxia type 1	CAG	progressive ataxia, dysarthria, dysmetria.




Disease	Repe ats	clinical features
Friedreich's ataxia	GAA	Progressive ataxia,dysarthria,  hypertrophiccardiomyopathy.

question: which of the following statements is true about the pathology of achalasia cardia?
options:
a)Relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter
b)Defective peristalsis
c)Decreased release of NO and vIP in the distal part of esophagus
d)Decreased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter
solution:
Achalasia cardia is characterized by decreased release of NO(nitric oxide) and vIP(vasoactive intestinal polypeptide) in the distal part of esophagus.
Normally, NO and vIP are secreted by the inhibitory neurons of the Auerbach's plexus in the    distal esophagus. This leads to relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). In achalasia cardia, these inhibitory neurons degenerate leading to decreased release of NO and vIP. This    causes increased LES tone.
The triad of achalasia cardia is as follows:
• Incomplete relaxation of LES
• Increased tone of LES
• Absent peristalsis (aperistalisis)

question: A patient presents with midline swelling in the neck. Biopsy revealing Orphan Annie eye nuclei is shown in the image below. what is the diagnosis?
options:
a)Follicular carcinoma
b)papillary carcinoma
c)Toxic nodular goitre
d)Medullary carcinoma
solution:
The presence of empty appearing nuclei, also called Orphan Annie eye nuclei as seen in the above image is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.
Microscopic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma include:
• Branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk
• covering epithelium is simple or stratified cuboidal
• Orphan Annie eye nuclei -
• Empty-appearing nuclei due to dispersed chromatin
• They are diagnostic, regardless of papillary architecture
• Psammoma bodies - concentric calcified structures
• Foci of lymphatic invasion
The image below shows papillary thyroid carcinoma with characteristic Orphan Annie eye nuclei:











Note: orphan Annie refers to a comic book character with empty appearing eyes.

question:
A 51-year-old male patient came with complaints of hematuria to the clinic. on examination, he was normotensive and had pedal edema. Investigations revealed the patient had no
glycosuria and had a creatinine of 9. His renal biopsy is shown below. which of the following investigations should be done to identify the disease?
options:
a)ANA
b)Anti GBM antibodies
c)HIV RNA
d)urine immunoelectrophoresis
solution:
Based on the given clinical history and microscopy showing crescents, rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is suspected. Among the given options, anti- GBM antibody     testing should be done, since it is a part of the work-up of RPGN.



Type 1 RPGN includes renal limited disease and Goodpasture's disease. In this condition,
antibodies are produced against the non-collagenous domain of the α3 chain of collagen IV of the GBM.
Microscopy findings of Goodpasture's disease are:



• Immunofluorescence - linear deposits of Ig and complement along the glomerular basement membrane
• Electron microscopy - wrinkling of the glomerular basement membrane with focal
disruptions without any immune complex deposition.
A variant of Goodpasture's disease with pulmonary involvement is known as Goodpasture's syndrome.
option A: ANA testing is done if SLE is suspected. Electron microscopy will show immune complex deposits.
option C: HIV RNA testing is done in immunodeficiency syndrome associated with weight loss. Electron microscopy will show diffuse podocyte injury with complete foot process effacement.
Tubuloreticular inclusions will be seen in endothelial cells.
option D: urine electrophoresis is done if nephrotic syndrome is suspected.

question: A 5o-year-old man presented with a retroperitoneal mass. Biopsy from the lesion is shown in the image below. Molecular analysis revealed t(12;16). what is the most likely condition?
options:
a)Myxoid Liposarcoma
b)Lipoma
c)spindle lipoma
d)polymorphic lipoma
solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myxoid liposarcoma.
The image shows abundant ground substance, with branching capillaries and a few immature adipocytes.
Liposarcoma is the most common sarcoma in adults and is usually seen in the 5th to 6th decade of life. They commonly occur in the deep soft tissues of the proximal extremities and in the
retroperitoneum.
Histologically the liposarcomas are divided into three subtypes:
• well-differentiated liposarcoma: It consists of mature adipocytes and scattered spindle cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. It is associated with amplification of 12q13-q15.
• Myxoid liposarcoma: It contains abundant basophilic extracellular matrix with branching
capillaries. Few immature adipocytes are found scattered within the matrix. It is associated with t(12;16).
• pleomorphic liposarcoma: It consists of sheets of anaplastic cells with bizarre nuclei and few immature adipocytes.
Among the three subtypes, the pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while the well-differentiated is least malignant. Myxoid liposarcoma has
intermediate malignancy behaviour.

question: Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in which condition?
options:
a)Infective endocarditis
b)Rheumatic heart disease
c)Libman-sacks endocarditis
d)Non-bacterial thrombotic carditis
solution:
Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in infective endocarditis.
Infective endocarditis is characterized by the presence of large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves. Aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly affected, however, in some cases, the right heart valves may be involved.



vegetations may be single or multiple and may involve one or more valves. Embolization often  occurs and may lead to septic infarcts or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgement due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli.

question:
A 23-year-old male patient presented with a history of fatigue and tiredness. on investigation, he was found to have Hb = 9 gm% and MCV =101 FL. peripheral smear examination showed   macrocytic RBC and hypersegmented neutrophils. which of the following is the most likely
etiology?
options:
a)Lead poisoning
b)Iron deficiency anemia
c)Hemolytic anemia
d)chronic alcoholism
solution:
The given findings are suggestive of macrocytic anaemia, which can be seen in chronic alcoholics.
Anemic patients with a peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils are important characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia.
Chronic alcoholics also have deficiency of folic acid due to:
• Trapping of folate within the liver
• Excessive urinary loss
• Disordered folate metabolism
• Inadequate dietary intake is frequently encountered in chronic alcoholics

question: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and   painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. what is the most likely diagnosis?
options:
a)peutz Jegher syndrome
b)villous adenoma
c)Juvenile polyp
d)Tubular adenoma
solution:
The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp.






Juvenile polyps are malformations of epithelium and lamina propria commonly located in the rectum. It is seen in children <5 years of age. The typical presentation is painless rectal
bleeding. sometimes there may be a proliferating rectal mass.
The disease may be sporadic or syndromic.
• sporadic juvenile polyp occurs as a single mass and is called retention polyp.
• Juvenile polyposis syndrome is characterized by multiple hamartomatous polyps, which may be premalignant.
Morphologically, both of these types are indistinguishable.
• Gross appearance: They appear as pedunculated, smooth reddish lesions, and with cystic spaces.
• Microscopic appearance: The cysts appear as dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris.
Note: complex glandular architecture and the presence of smooth muscle cutting through the lamina propria are seen in peutz-Jeghers polyps.

question: A 2o-year-old patient presented to the clinic with a history of malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite. Duodenal biopsy of the patient showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and   cD8+ cells in lamina propria. what is the most probable diagnosis?
options:
a)Environmental enteropathy
b)celiac disease
c)whipple's disease
d)chronic pancreatitis
solution:
The clinical presentation and the histopathological findings are suggestive of celiac disease.
celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy where HLA DQ2 and DQ8 are
expressed. In the small intestine, peptides of gluten are presented to helper T cells which mediate mucosal inflammation. Antiendomysial and anti-tTG antibodies are found in serological studies.
clinically, malabsorption syndrome with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and marked weight loss is
seen along with chronic refractory anemia. Dermatitis herpetiformis is seen in 1o% of patients
with celiac disease. Microscopic findings show villi atrophy, villi flattening, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial T lymphocytes (IEL).



option A: Environmental enteropathy / tropical sprue is seen in tropical areas with poor
sanitation. It is believed to be caused by one or more infectious agents that respond to antibiotics. Mucosa shows variable villous atrophy.
option c: whipple's disease is a multisystemic disease caused by T.whipplei. small intestinal biopsy shows PAs-positive macrophages.

question: A 3-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash and swelling of   her hands and feet since past 5 days. There is desquamative skin rash, oedema of hands and   feet, erythema of palms and soles, oral erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. what is the likely condition?
options:
a)kawasaki disease
b)Measles
c)scarlet fever
d)Henoch schonlein purpura
solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.
kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It is commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age.
clinical features include:
• Fever
• conjunctival and oral erythema
• Blistering, edema of hands and feet
• Erythema of palms and soles
• Desquamative rash
• cervical lymphadenopathy
The disease is usually self-limiting. In some cases, the disease may involve coronary artery leading to thrombosis and acute myocardial infarction. Intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin may be    given to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.

question: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases?
options:
a)steroid resistant glomerulonephritis
b)Minimal change disease
c)Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
d)chronic glomerulonephritis
solution:
Effacement of the podocyte foot processes is characteristically seen in minimal change disease (McD), which is also called lipoid nephrosis.
It is also seen in other conditions such as membranous nephropathy and focal segmental
glomerulosclerosis. since the podocytes are affected in these diseases, they are also known as podocytopathies.
The effacement of foot process can only be observed on electron microscopy.

question: Thrombosis is initiated by:
options:
a)platelet activation
b)Endothelial injury
c)coagulation cascade
d)vasoconstriction of vessels
solution:
Thrombosis is initiated by endothelial injury.
Thrombosis is is the formation of a blood clot inside a blood vessel, obstructing the flow of blood through the circulatory system.



Three primary abnormalities, often referred to as virchow triad, are known to induce thrombosis. They include:
• Endothelial injury - most important factor
• stasis or turbulent blood flow
• Hypercoagulability of the blood

question: A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. Blood tests show elevated TsH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Histopathological examination revealed  the presence of Hurthle ■cells. what is the most likely diagnosis?
options:
a)Hashimoto thyroiditis
b)Graves' disease
c)Follicular carcinoma
d)Medullary carcinoma of thyroid
solution:
This clinical scenario with the presence of Hurthle cells is suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
It is an autoimmune disease, characterized by the gradual destruction of the thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is commonly seen in women between 45 to 65 years of age. It is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase.
Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is well demarcated from the adjacent structures.
Microscopic features include:
• Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well developed germinal centers
• Atrophied thyroid follicles
• The epithelial cells lining the follicles contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm
• This is called oncocytic metaplasia
• These cells are called Hurthle cells

question:
A 52-year-old male patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils and an
endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. which of the following conditions is likely to be seen this patient?
options:
a)vitamin B12 deficiency
b)Folate deficiency
c)pyridoxine deficiency
d)Niacin deficiency
solution:
The given findings are suggestive of pernicious anemia, which is associated with atrophic gastritis and vitamin B12 deficiency.
Anemic patient with a peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented
neutrophils are important characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia. vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency are the main causes of megaloblastic anemia.
pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies
which impairs the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF). This is required for the uptake of vitamin B12. There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of
each of these include:
• Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intinsic factor (IF).
• Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors.
• Autoantibody type III acts against the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factor.
These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells.

question:
A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of her breast.
Histopathological examination of the mass showed cells in mucin pools and faint nuclei. what is the most likely diagnosis?
options:
a)colloid carcinoma
b)papillary carcinoma
c)Medullary carcinoma
d)Lobular carcinoma
solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of colloid or mucinous carcinoma of the breast.
Colloid carcinoma is an invasive breast carcinoma, which shows intracellular and extracellular mucin deposition.



on histopathological examination, extracellular type shows tumor cells with faint nuclei, arranged in clusters, floating in lakes or pools of mucin. In intracellular type, nuclei are pushed to the
periphery to form a signet ring appearance.



option B: Microscopic image of papillary carcinoma of the breast showing true papillae with a leaf-like arrangement of fibrovascular tissue lined by the tumor cells is shown below.






option C: Microscopic image of medullary carcinoma of the breast consisting of sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures (anaplastic cells), lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate is shown    below.





option D: Microscopic image of lobular carcinoma of the breast shows infiltrating small
monomorphic discohesive tumor cells arranged in an Indian-file or single-file pattern is shown below.

question: which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease?
options:
a)Failure of migration of neural crest cells
b)Loss of ganglion cells
c)visceral myopathy
d)obstruction by inflammatory stricture
solution:
Hirschsprung disease occurs due to the failure of migration of the neural crest cells to the bowel wall.
During normal embryogenesis, the neural crest cells migrate from the caecum to the rectum. The enteric neuronal plexuses develop from these migrated neural crest cells.
In Hirschsprung disease, there is an arrest in the migration of these cells, which leads to the development of a distal intestinal segment that is devoid of Meissner (submucosal) and the



Auerbach (myenteric) plexus. Hence this segment is referred to as the aganglionic segment.
As a result, there is a lack of coordination in the peristaltic contractions and functional
obstruction, which further leads to the dilation of the intestine proximal to the affected segment, leading to congenital megacolon. Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating the absence of
ganglion cells in biopsy sections.


some conditions may cause acquired megacolon. These include:
• chagas disease, due to the loss of ganglion cells
• visceral myopathy
• obstruction by neoplasm or inflammatory stricture
• Toxic megacolon complicating ulcerative colitis
• Functional psychosomatic disorders

question: premature aging in werner syndrome is due to:
options:
a)Increased telomerase activity
b)Defect in DNA helicase
c)Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity
d)None of the above
solution:
premature aging in werner syndrome is due to a defect in DNA helicase.
DNA helicase is involved in DNA replication and repair and other functions requiring DNA
unwinding. A defect in this enzyme causes rapid accumulation of damaged chromosomes that may mimic the injury that normally accumulates during cellular aging.

question: A 24-year-old presented with swelling in the wrist joint. Histopathological examination of the swelling revealed spindle cells with palisading of the nuclei and verocay bodies. which of the following is the most likely condition?
options:
a)schwannoma
b)Neurofibroma
c)Neuroma
d)Glioma
solution:
The histopathological examination is suggestive of schwannoma. Features showing spindle cells with palisading nuclei and verocay bodies are characteristic of schwannoma.



schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that abut the associated nerve
without invading it. They are commonly associated with inactivating mutations in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22q12.
Microscopically, it consists of dense areas called Antoni A, and loose areas called Antoni B.
• The Antoni A areas contain spindle cells that are arranged into intersecting fascicles. palisading  of nuclei is seen, with nuclear-free zones between them, forming structures called verocay bodies.
• The Antoni B areas contain spindle-shaped cells that are loosely arranged separated by prominent myxoid extracellular matrix.
The image below shows cellular Antoni A and paucicellullar Antoni B areas in schwannoma.


The image below shows verocay bodies in the Antoni-A area of vestibular schwannoma.

question: B-cells are induced to produce IgE by which of the following:
options:
a)IL-2
b)IL-4
c)IL-1
d)IL-6
solution: IL-4 stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE secreting plasma cells.

question: The lining epithelium of the respiratory tract of a middle-aged man who is a chronic smoker shows a change from columnar to stratified squamous epithelium, as depicted in the image   below. The change is called:
options:
a)Dysplasia
b)Hypertrophy
c)Atrophy
d)Metaplasia
solution:
The change described in the question is called metaplasia. It is defined as a reversible change in which one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type.
The table below shows various types of metaplasia:
GERD: Gastroesophageal reflux disease

Tissue	Metaplasia	cause
Airways	squamous metaplasia: Norm al pseudostratified epitheliu   m is replaced by the squamo  us epithelium.	chronic smoking,Deficiency of retinoic acid
urinary bladd er	squamous metaplasia: Norm  al transitional epithelium is r eplaced by squamous epitheli um.	Bladder stones
Esophagus	columnar metaplasia: Norma l squamous epithelium is repl aced by the glandular column ar epithelium (Barret's esoph  agus)	chronic GERD
cervix	squamous metaplasia: Norm al glandular epithelium may  be replaced by the squamous epithelium.	Low pH of the cervix
Muscle	connective tissue metaplasia: Formation of bone in the mu  scle tissue; (myositis ossifica   ns).	After intramuscular hemorrh age

question: Graft from identical twin is called:
options:
a)Allograft
b)Autograft
c)Isograft
d)xenograft
solution:
A graft from an identical twin is called an isograft.
Isograft is defined as an organ or tissue that is taken from a donor and is transplanted to a
recipient who has the same genetic constitution as the donor. For example, graft between identical twins.

question: Histology of reperfused myocardium:
options:
a)wavy fibres
b)Neutrophils in cardiac muscle
c)swelling of cells
d)Eosinophilc contraction band
solution:
Reperfused myocardium shows eosinophilic contraction bands on light microscopy. They occur   in irreversibly injured myocytes with damaged membranes, when blood supply is restored 12-24 hours after MI.
During ischemia, the intracellular levels of calcium are increased due to impaired calcium cycling and sarcolemmal damage. This leads to augmented and uncontrolled contraction of myofibrils
after reperfusion.
on microscopic examination, the irreversibly injured myocytes exhibit contraction bands that are intensely eosinophilic intracellular stripes. These contraction bands are composed of closely
packed sarcomeres.
Reperfused infarcts are usually hemorrhagic because the vasculature is injured during ischemia. This leads to bleeding after the flow is restored.

question: All-trans retinoic acid is used in the treatment of tumor that is associated with which of the following genetic aberrations?
options:
a)PML-RARA
b)BCRABL
c)cMYC
d)RUNX1 ETO
solution:
All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML), which is associated with PML-RARA fusion gene.
Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) is associated with a reciprocal translocation between  chromosomes 15 and 17 producing a PML-RARA fusion gene. This fusion gene encodes for a chimeric protein, which consists of a part of the PML protein and a part of the retinoic acid   receptor-α (RARα).
The normal RARα binds to the DNA and activates the transcription in the presence of retinoids.  However, the chimeric protein produced by PML-RARA has reduced affinity for retinoids. This     causes inhibition of transcription, thereby preventing gene expression for cellular differentiation. This leads to the accumulation of myeloid progenitor cells.
The condition is treated with all-trans retinoic acid. It binds to the PML-RARA chimeric protein.   This causes conformational change such that the protein regains its normal function and activates DNA transcription.

question:
A 12-year-old child presented with 15 days of cough. On examination, cervical
lymphadenopathy was noted and the lymph node biopsy showed the following features. what is the most probable diagnosis?
options:
a)Tuberculosis
b)Leprosy
c)sarcoidosis
d)syphilis
solution:
The histopathological picture showing the caseating granuloma, eosinophilic necrotic debris
known as caseation, bordered by collections of epithelioid cells, Langhan giant cells (horse shoe shape) and lymphocytes and clinical history is suggestive of tuberculosis.
Clinically, tuberculosis presents with chronic cough, fever, weight loss, swollen lymph nodes.
other options:
option B- Leprosy presents with skin lesions and nerve involvement with loss of sensation.
option C- sarcoidosis shows giant cells with cytoplasmic inclusions, non-caseating granuloma with fibroblastic proliferation at the periphery.



option D- syphilis shows thickened capsule/ hyperplasia of capsule accompanied by fibrosis, perivascular inflammation, and infiltration of chronic inflammatory cells.
The below image shows histopathological findings seen in tuberculosis

question:
A 3o-year-old woman with a long history of dyspnea, chronic cough with sputum, and    wheezing died of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. she was not a



smoker or an alcoholic. The lung at autopsy is shown in the image below. which of the following is most likely to cause the pathological changes shown?
options:
a)Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency
b)cystic fibrosis
c)Mutation in dynein arms
d)Antibodies against type-IV collagen
solution:
The above gross specimen shows emphysematous damage involving enlargement of the entire acinus suggestive of panacinar emphysema. It is caused due to alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency.
In panacinar (panlobular) emphysema, the acini are uniformly enlarged from the level of the
respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli. It occurs commonly in the lower zones and in the anterior margins of the lung and is most severe at the bases.
The image below shows panacinar emphysema.

question: A 6-foot-5-inch man undergoing a routine physical examination was found to have an early   diastolic murmur. His family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition.
options:
a)Autosomal dominant
b)Autosomal recessive
c)X-linked
d)Mitochondrial
solution:
The patient's height and the presence of early diastolic murmur in the given clinical scenario are suggestive of Marfan syndrome. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant disorder. The family     pedigree confirms the mode of inheritance.
The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.


patients with Marfan syndrome have pleiotropic manifestations:
• skeletal systems - Tall and decreased upper to lower segment ratio with long arms, hands, and fingers
• Deformities of the chest wall, vertebral column, and foot arches
• cardiovascular abnormalities - mitral valve prolapse leading to mitral
regurgitation and dilatation of aortic root leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture.
• ocular - superio-temporal lens dislocation
